title: Travel: Watch the Perseids meteor shower at boutique Miami hotel
text:
Hey there, you with the stars in your eyes — or you, who wants to see stars with your eyes!
There’s a meteor shower called Perseids on the horizon, and if you position yourself in the right place you may be lucky enough to watch the shooting stars streak through the midnight sky.
Birdwatchers gather to see what they can find in the Keys. Contributed The Perseids meteor shower, named because meteors appear to fall from a point in the constellation Perseus, is set to take place the night of Aug. 12.
In Miami Beach, Sense Beach House is offering guests its rooftop oasis to watch the falling stars from midnight and 2 a.m. on Aug. 12. The boutique hotel will enhance the show by serving Champagne to star watchers.
Because the hotel is on Ocean Drive far enough away from all the city lights in downtown Miami, it should be a good spot to view the show.
Sense Beach House is offering guests their rooftop oasis to watch the meteor shower on Aug. 12. The South Beach boutique hotel will be serving Champagne to make the night extra special. Contributed For reservations, visit www.sensebeachhouse.com .
Spotting fine-feathered friends
Like stargazers, bird watchers are often looking up, too. And if you like to watch birds, consider the Florida Keys, a top destination for bird watching all year.
Resident and migrating warblers, vireos, tanagers and thrushes share the habitat with white-crowned pigeons, tidal waders and nesting sea birds.
One good option for birders is the 12-county, 116-site Great Florida Birding and Wildlife Trail . The South Florida section of the trail has a dozen Keys native habitat stops including the National Key Deer Refuge, Dagny Johnson Key Largo Hammock Botanical State Park, Long Key State Park and Dry Tortugas National Park 70 miles off Key West in the Gulf of Mexico. For trail information, visit www.floridabirdingtrail.com .
In the Lower Keys, the National Key Deer Refuge’s 9,000-plus acres of mangrove forests, freshwater and salt marsh wetlands, pine rockland forests and tropical hardwood hammocks are an annual stopping point for migratory birds and a winter home to many North American bird species. The refuge is just off U.S. Highway 1 at mile marker 30.5 on Big Pine Key.
At Long Key State Park at mile marker 67.5, mangrove swamp, mudflat, rockland hammock, beach and coastal berm habitats are ripe for exploration. Roseate Spoonbills can be spotted dipping their round-tipped bills into the shallows at low tide.
In Key Largo, John Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park, at mile marker 102.5, gives bird watchers 3,000 acres of natural mangrove swamp, hardwood hammock and rocky coast. Gray kingbirds, short-tailed hawks and mangrove cuckoos can be spotted from walking trails.
For more birding sites in the Keys, www.fla-keys.com/ecotourism .
